summary: Herbert Itkin was a person of interest to the CIA and FBI due to alleged Mafia connections, espionage activities, and claims of providing information to U.S. intelligence. He was a former employee of both the CIA and FBI. Documents indicate investigations into his background, travel restrictions in Santo Domingo, and his use as an informant on Haitian exiles. He attempted to involve the CIA in a custody battle, exposing CIA agent Bernard E. MONCURE. Australian Justice A.R. Moffitt requested information on Itkin's reliability and status between 1964 and 1969 for an inquiry into organized crime in New South Wales. Itkin claimed CIA involvement and possible connections to Allen Dulles, prompting internal investigations and verification efforts. The documents span from 1968 to 1977, indicating sustained interest in Itkin's activities and associations.
